It is possible to allow end users and other key individuals within your organization to record feedback about Book Pages and other digital learning objects.  To do this, the Feedback functionality must be turned on in the Playback Settings and the Feedback button them appears in the Trainer (the content player toolbar).  For more information on gather feedback about Book Pages and other Enable Now digital learning content objects, refer to this video.

entry.title: Re: "Managing Business Role Changes After an Upgrade" app
entry.content:
Hello @naoakisaruyama 

Single change refers to one upgrade delta for a role, such as replacing or deprecating a catalogue or applying a restriction. The app works best when you focus on one type of change at a time for a specific role. SAP Help Portal: Manage Business Role Changes After Upgrade

Multiple changes indicate that the role has more than one type of modification, such as catalogue replacements and restriction updates or significant differences from its template. SAP Help Portal-Best Practices for Managing Business Role Changes After an Upgrade

You can also check. SAP Support Portal-KBA-3093696 - How to manage business role changes after system upgrade

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: SAP IQ to SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake Migration Overview
entry.content:
Migrating from SAP IQ to SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake (HDL) involves moving your existing data and schema from the on-premise SAP IQ database to the cloud-based HDL. SAP offers a streamlined path to facilitate this journey with its SAP IQ to SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake (HDL) migration utility.
In this blog, we’ll walk you through the migration process, highlight key prerequisites, and break down the components of the migration utility to help you make a smooth transition.

Overview of the Migration Process

Migrating from an on-premise SAP IQ database to SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake involves multiple coordinated steps. The primary phases include:

• Pre-migration checks
• Schema unload and data extraction
• Schema loading and data loading
• Post-migration validation

To support this process, SAP provides an open-source Data Lake Migration utility via GitHub: SAP-samples/iq-to-hdl-migration. This toolset automates much of the migration workflow and ensures compatibility with your target data lake environment.

Prerequisites & Key Requirements

Before initiating the migration, you’ll need to ensure your environment meets the following criteria:

Platform Compatibility: Supported platforms: Linux or Microsoft Windows

Python Environment

    • Python 3.10.x or higher is required
    • Mandatory Python modules: parmiko, pyodbc, psutil

SAP IQ Version: Your SAP IQ system must be running version 16.1 or later

Locale/Collation Support

All locales and collations supported by the data lake Relational Engine are supported except:

    • EUC_TAIWAN
    • CESU8BIN

Target Environment

    • SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake (Relational Engine + Data Lake Files) must be provisioned
    • Migration uses data lake Files containers only, running on Amazon, Azure, Google Cloud.

Data Lake Client Package

    • The SAP HANA data lake client is required to load data into the Relational Engine and is recommended to be installed on a different machine than the SAP IQ server.
    • Ensure the Data Lake Client can access migration scripts in <utility_scripts_dir>/iq-to-hdl-migration

Migration Process Breakdown

The migration utility consists of three main components, each with a specific role in the migration process.

1. Pre-Migration Utility

Script: pre_migration.py

This utility checks your on-premise SAP IQ system for potential migration blockers such as:

    • Incompatible or unsupported features
    • Unsupported server options
    • User configurations
    • Database artifacts

Configuration:

Pre-migration utility depends on a correctly configured premigration_config.json located in the /Common directory of the Data Lake Migration Utility to function effectively.

Here's a breakdown of the required and optional parameters:

Parameter

Description

Host_Name

Hostname of the SAP IQ coordinator or simplex server.

Port_Number

Port number of the SAP IQ server. Use an integer (e.g., 1912) - no quotes.

DBA_User

SAP IQ DBA user name.

DBA_Pwd

(Optional) DBA user password. Leave as " " to be prompted at runtime.

IQ_Server_On_Same_Host

Specifies if the data lake client and SAP IQ Server are on the same host. Values: Yes or No.

IQ_Host_Login_Id

SSH login ID to connect to the SAP IQ Server host. Optional if both components run on the same host.

IQ_Host_Login_Pwd

SSH login password. Leave as " " to be prompted.

ENC

Encryption between client and server. Options: None, Simple, or TLS(<TLS Client Options>).

IQ_Version

Must be set to 16.1 (the supported version).

IQ_Server_Install_Path

Path to the SAP IQ Server installation.

Datalake_Client_Install_Path

Path to the 17.1 SAP Data Lake client installation.

Ensure all values are accurate before proceeding.

Running the Pre-migration Utility:

Assuming:

    • The utility is located in /home/user/iq-to-hdl-migration/Pre_Migration
    • The config file is at /home/user/iq-to-hdl-migration/Common/premigration_config.json
    •  SAP IQ server is installed at /opt/sap/iqserver

Step-by-Step Commands:

    • Source the SAP IQ environment:  source /opt/sap/iqserver/IQ.sh
    • Change to the Pre_Migration directory:  cd /home/user/iq-to-hdl-migration/Pre_Migration
    • Run the utility:  python3 pre_migration.py --config_file ../Common/premigration_config.json
    • Monitor progress in real time:  tail -f pre_migration.log
    • Output Files (after successful execution) , generated in: /home/user/iq-to-hdl-migration/Pre_Migration
      • pre_migration.out – Lists unsupported/incompatible artifacts.
      • pre_migration.log – Logs all actions, helpful for troubleshooting.

2. Migration Utility

Script: migration.py

Handles the extraction of your schema and data from SAP IQ to a local directory.

Configuration:

Before running the migration.py script, you must prepare the migration_config.json file with the correct values tailored to your environment. Here's a detailed guide to each parameter:

Parameter

Description

Datalake_Client_Install_Path

Path to the SAP Data Lake Files Client (version 17.1) installation directory.

Extract_Path

A shared directory where all extracted data will be temporarily stored during the migration.

Directory_Name

The name of the target directory in the Data Lake Files container. Must be a string.

Files_endpoint

REST API endpoint URL for the Data Lake Files container.

Cert_path

Path to the certificate used for secure access to the Data Lake Files container.

Key_path

Path to the private key corresponding to the above certificate.

Host_Name

Hostname of your SAP IQ coordinator/simplex server.

Port_Number

The port number used by SAP IQ (e.g., 1912). Must be entered as an integer (without quotes).

DBA_User

The DBA user name used for authentication.

DBA_Pwd

(Optional) Password for the DBA user. If left as "", you will be prompted to enter it securely during execution.

Client_Num_Conn

Number of client connections per server used for data extraction.

IQ_Server_On_Same_Host

Indicates if the SAP IQ server and the data lake client are on the same host. Supported values: Yes or No.

IQ_Host_Login_Id

SSH login ID to connect to the SAP IQ host. Optional if IQ_Server_On_Same_Host is Yes.

IQ_Host_Login_Pwd

Password for the SSH login. If left empty (""), you’ll be prompted at runtime.

ENC

Encryption between client and server. Options: None, Simple, or TLS(<TLS Client Options>).

Batch_Size_GB

(Optional) Batch size in GB for extraction. Enter 0 or omit to disable batching.

IQ_Server_Install_Path

The installation path of your SAP IQ server.

IQ_Version

SAP IQ major version. Only 16.1 is supported.

Pre-requisites Before Running migration.py

Before running the migration utility, ensure you’ve completed these critical steps:

    • Run pre_migration.py utility: This checks your SAP IQ environment for unsupported artifacts. Review the pre_migration.out file carefully and address any flagged issues.
    • Configure migration_config.json: Update this configuration file in the Common directory with your environment-specific parameters.
    • Shared Extraction Path: The <extract_path> you specify in your config file must be accessible by all SAP IQ nodes in your environment.

Running the migration Utility:

Migration utility extracts your SAP IQ schema and data, unloading it to a shared location.

Extraction Modes:

You can choose how much to unload by specifying one of these switches:

    • Schema only: --onlyschema y
    • Data only: --onlydata y
    • Full extraction (schema + data): --fullextraction y

Note: Only one of these options can be used per run.

Assuming:

    • SAP IQ server is installed at /opt/sap/iqserver
    • SAP client is installed at /opt/sap/datalake-client
    • You want to extract both schema and data (full extraction)
    • Your shared extraction path is /data/migration_extract
    • Your config file is located at  /home/user/iq-to-hdl-migration/Common/migration_config.json
    • The migration utility will be run on the SAP IQ server host

Step-by-Step Commands:

    • Source the SAP IQ server environment:  source /opt/sap/iqserver/IQ.sh
    • Run the migration utility with full extraction mode enabled: python3 migration.py --config_file /home/user/iq-to-hdl-migration/Common/migration_config.json --fullextraction y
    • (Optional) Specify the Mode Switch, If your SAP IQ server was not started in read-only mode (without -iqro flag), add the write mode option: python3 migration.py --config_file /home/user/iq-to-hdl-migration/Common/migration_config.json  --fullextraction y --mode w
    • Output Files and Folders Generated by migration.py

      Once completed, the utility generates several important files and directories at <extract_path>/Migration_Data:

      File/Folder

      Description

      Extracted_Data (folder)

      Contains subfolders for each table with data files and corresponding SQL load scripts.

      reload.sql

      Schema and artifact definitions extracted using the iqunload utility.

      iq_tables.list

      List of all tables with row counts and sizes in your SAP IQ database.

      AutoUpdated_Reload.sql

      Contains unsupported or differently supported artifacts commented out for review.

      ExtractedTables.out

      Lists all tables extracted along with row counts and table types (BASE, FOREIGN).

      extractFailure.err

      Tables that failed extraction, with failure reasons.

      Additionally, a comprehensive log file containing detailed logs of the entire migration run is created at: <utility_scripts_dir>/iq-to-hdl-migration/Migration/migration.log

3. Data Copy and Load Utilities

These tools handle the data movement from local storage into the SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake.

Data Copy:

Script: copy_hdlfs.py

The copy_hdlfs.py script is part of the Data Lake Migration Utility and is designed to upload extracted data to the Data Lake Files container.

The utility requires the migration_config.json configuration file, which should be located in the Common directory.

Prerequisites: Before running the copy_hdlfs.py script, ensure you’ve completed the following steps:

    • You have executed the migration.py utility to extract schema and data from your on-premise SAP IQ system.
    • You have successfully created a Data Lake Relational Engine instance in your SAP HANA Cloud environment.

Running copy_hdlfs.py: python3 copy_hdlfs.py --config_file /home/user/iq-to-hdl-migration/Common/migration_config.json

Data Load:

Script: load_schema_and_data.py (Loads schema and data into the Relational Engine)

Prerequisites: Before you run the load_schema_and_data.py script, make sure you've completed the following steps:

    • Update Configuration
      Edit the load_config.json file located in the Common directory with the necessary parameters for your environment.
    • Copy Schema and Data Files
      Use the copy_hdlfs.py script to copy the extracted schema and data from your on-premise SAP IQ to your data lake's Files container.

Configuration:

The load_config.json configuration file holds all the necessary parameters for the load_schema_and_data.py utility.

Below is a breakdown of the parameters you need to configure, along with explanations for each:

Parameter

Description

Datalake_Client_Install_Path

Path to the SAP Data Lake Files client installation directory (version 17.1).

Extract_Path

Shared directory location where the data extracted during migration is stored.

Directory_Name

Name of the directory in the Data Lake Files container where extracted SAP IQ data is copied.

Files_endpoint

REST API endpoint URL for accessing the Data Lake Files container.

Cert_path

Path to the certificate used for secure access to the Data Lake Files container.

Key_path

Path to the private key for certificate authentication.

HDLADMIN_User

Username for the HDLADMIN account.

HDLADMIN_Pwd

(Optional) Password for the HDLADMIN user. If left empty (""), you will be prompted to enter it securely.

HDL_Coord_Endpoint

Endpoint URL of the Data Lake Relational Engine coordinator node.

HDL_Worker_Endpoint

Endpoint URL of the Data Lake Relational Engine worker node.

HDL_Num_Worker_Conn

Total number of client connections to the worker node. Enter as an integer (no quotes).

HDL_Num_Coord_Conn

(Optional) Number of client connections to the coordinator node. Enter an integer or leave empty.

Object_Store_Copy_Validation

Validation flag for copied objects. Set to Yes or No. Important: If batch extraction is enabled (via Batch_Size_GB in migration_config.json), this must be set to No. Any other value will cause the load_schema_and_data.py script to fail.

Running the utility:

Assuming:

    • SAP client is installed at /opt/sap/datalake-client
    • You want to perform a full load (both schema and data).
    • Your config file (load_config.json) is located at  /home/user/iq-to-hdl-migration/Common/load_config.json

Step-by-Step Commands:

    • Source the Data Lake environment: source /opt/sap/datalake-client/IQ.sh
    • Navigate to the Migration Directory and run the desired load command based on your needs:

      Load Type

      Command

      Schema only

      python3 load_schema_and_data.py --config_file /home/user/iq-to-hdl-migration/Common/load_config.json --onlyschema y

      Data only

      python3 load_schema_and_data.py --config_file /home/user/iq-to-hdl-migration/Common/load_config.json --onlydata y

      Schema + Data (Full Load)

      python3 load_schema_and_data.py --config_file/home/user/iq-to-hdl-migration/Common/load_config.json --fullload y

      After Execution:

      Check this directory for logs and results: <extract_path>/Migration_Data

      Key files include:
      • HDL_LoadedTables.out – Successfully loaded tables
      • HDL_LoadFailure.err – Tables that failed to load
      • HDL_LoadSchema.log – Schema load log
      • <utility_scripts_dir>/iq-to-hdl-migration/Migration/load_schema_and_data.log – Full utility log
      • /HDL_Conn_Logs/ – Per-table DBISQL logs

Post-Migration Validation:

Data Validation

  • After running load_schema_and_data.py:
    • A row-count validation is performed for each table.
    • If row counts do not match, the transaction is rolled back and not committed.
    • This ensures data integrity in the migrated environment.

Login and User Management

  • Default users created: These are SAP internal accounts only (not accessible to customers).
    • saptu
    • sapsupport

Privileges and Roles

  • Some privileges/roles are unsupported in the Data Lake Relational Engine.
  • During migration:
    • These unsupported roles/privileges are revoked automatically.

Post-Migration Cleanup Steps:

  • Remove Migration Data from Files Container
  • Remove Migration Scripts from SAP IQ

Known Limitations

File Size Restriction: The hdlfscli utility currently does not support files larger than 95 GB. SAP is reportedly working on a workaround for Windows-based systems

entry.title: Re: RE-FX Contracts- Reversal
entry.content: Hello Andre. We use only GUI transactions. So, I used this T-code RECEEPRV. However, I noticed that when I select the "reverse last run only" checkbox, the system recognises and reverses only the asset postings whereas it is unselected, it can reverse all the postings. Do you know if it is a configuration issue or we can accept it and not select this checkbox to process with the reversal ?

entry.title: Re: Send DOCMAS without attached files (Originals)
entry.content:
I know I’m 16 years late to this thread, but I recently faced the same issue and found a solution that might still help others:

You can filter out segments of the IDoc via transaction BD56.

  • Enter the IDoc type DOCMAS.
  • Specify the connection (sender and receiver)
  • Then exclude the segment E1DRAWFILES, which contains the original’s information.

This way the IDoc is transferred successfully without the originals.

entry.title: How Localization as a Service Delivers Long-Term Business Value
entry.content:
In today’s global economy, enterprises no longer compete within the boundaries of a single market. Growth strategies are increasingly international, with companies seeking opportunities across continents. Yet with opportunity comes complexity. Every new country adds another layer of tax laws, statutory reporting formats, payment standards, and compliance obligations.

For CFOs, CIOs, and compliance leaders, localization has become one of the most persistent obstacles to global expansion. The rules are constantly changing, and traditional approaches such as custom coding, manual interventions, and ad-hoc solutions often create a patchwork system that is expensive to maintain and vulnerable to risk.

It is clear that localization can no longer be treated as a one-time project. Instead, it must be seen as a continuous capability. This is where the model of Localization as a Service comes in, transforming compliance from a burden into a long-term driver of business value.

At Crimson Technology Partners, we believe that adopting Localization as a Service is one of the most strategic investments enterprises can make to future-proof their operations and unlock sustainable global growth.

Moving Beyond Compliance: From Cost to Value

When many organizations hear “localization,” their instinct is to think of compliance: keeping tax reports accurate, ensuring invoices follow local standards, or adapting to new e-invoicing mandates. Compliance is, of course, essential. But limiting localization to this view risks missing its larger potential.

Localization as a Service reframes compliance into a strategic enabler.

It enables scalability by allowing businesses to enter new markets without reinventing compliance processes each time. It provides consistency by harmonizing localization across regions while aligning with global business objectives. It delivers flexibility through rapid updates when regulations change, keeping systems current without major disruption.

This shift transforms localization from being a defensive, compliance-driven cost center into a proactive, business-enabling function.

The Technology Foundation: CLT and Beyond

SAP has recognized the complexity of localization and responded with the Configuration Localization Tool (CLT) in S/4HANA Cloud. CLT provides pre-delivered country versions for more than 60 regions in over 30 languages. More importantly, it allows businesses to configure and extend coverage to as many as 160 regions worldwide.

CLT addresses several critical needs such as statutory reporting, tax determination, electronic document compliance, and payment format standardization. For enterprises with global ambitions, this creates a strong foundation.

Yet CLT alone does not address every need. Every market contains nuances, and many organizations require extensions that go beyond standard capabilities. This is where Crimson adds differentiated value.

Accelerating Extensibility with Crimson’s No-Code Platform in SAP BTP

At Crimson Technology Partners, we enhance SAP’s localization framework through our no-code platform on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). This capability allows clients to extend their ERP systems side by side with SAP core functionality, without the delays and costs associated with traditional development.

With our no-code approach, businesses can build country-specific enhancements quickly, deploy custom payment formats or reporting structures rapidly, automate regulatory adjustments without heavy reliance on developer resources, and integrate local requirements seamlessly into core processes.

This acceleration is crucial in a world where compliance deadlines are often short and penalties for non-compliance are steep. By combining CLT with Crimson’s BTP extensibility, organizations can meet regulatory obligations faster and scale into new markets with confidence.

The Power of AI in Localization

Technology is evolving, and artificial intelligence is now reshaping how localization is delivered. Instead of waiting for manual monitoring or reactive updates, AI enables organizations to anticipate and adapt to change proactively.

Crimson is embedding AI-driven intelligence into our Localization as a Service model. This includes automated monitoring of regulatory bulletins and government portals across multiple countries, predictive insights that forecast potential regulatory trends and model their business impact, smart recommendations that suggest configuration adjustments in CLT or trigger workflows in BTP, and anomaly detection that flags issues before they escalate into compliance violations.

The combination of AI with CLT and BTP creates a localization framework that is not only compliant but also intelligent, adaptive, and proactive.

The Human Expertise: Why Partnerships Still Matter

While technology is powerful, compliance is not purely a technical problem. Regulations are nuanced and subject to interpretation. Local tax rules may require subjective judgment, and cultural or procedural norms often influence how compliance is executed.

This is why human expertise remains essential. At Crimson, our specialists interpret regulatory requirements, adapt technology appropriately, and ensure that localization aligns with both legal standards and business objectives.

Our teams provide continuous monitoring of regulatory landscapes across markets, pre-built templates and compliance packs based on proven project experience, and advisory services that connect localization requirements with strategic business planning.

The result is a model where technology, AI, and human expertise reinforce one another.

Long-Term Business Value

Enterprises that embrace Localization as a Service unlock a wide range of benefits. They mitigate risks by avoiding costly penalties, audit failures, and reputational damage. They improve operational efficiency by reducing the need for internal teams to chase updates or manage fragmented customizations. They accelerate market entry with scalable templates and rapid extensibility. They gain agility and resilience by responding to regulatory change proactively with AI insights and BTP no-code capabilities. Most importantly, they enable leadership teams to focus on growth, innovation, and customer value instead of firefighting compliance issues.

In essence, Localization as a Service turns what was once a constant risk into a sustainable source of competitive advantage.

Crimson Technology Partners: Your Long-Term Ally

Crimson Technology Partners brings together three essential elements: the robust coverage of SAP’s CLT, our no-code platform on SAP BTP for accelerated extensibility, and AI-driven monitoring and automation for predictive compliance.

Backed by years of regulatory expertise, we ensure that clients achieve not only technical compliance but also business agility and long-term value. Our role is to stand beside enterprises as they grow globally, ensuring that localization never becomes a barrier but always a pathway.

Localization is not a one-time project. It is a continuous requirement that, when managed as a service, delivers far more than compliance. It reduces risk, enables efficiency, drives agility, and supports strategic global growth.

By combining CLT, no-code extensibility on BTP, AI-powered intelligence, and regulatory expertise, Crimson Technology Partners helps clients transform compliance into a foundation for long-term success.

Localization as a Service is not simply about avoiding fines. It is about enabling global ambition with confidence, and that is the business value that lasts.

Speak with Crimson Technology Partners today to explore how Localization as a Service can strengthen your compliance and accelerate your

entry.title: Re: How to develop a Fiori app to run in online AND offli...
entry.content:
Hi Claudia

Even offline apps run in online mode sometimes - that's how they sync data before going offline and after returning to the network from offline.  So you just need to create an offline capable app. The recommended approach is to use SAP BTP mobile services to provide the syncing capability so try the BTP service catalog https://www.sap.com/australia/products/technology-platform/mobile-services.html

            "Content-Type: application/json",

            "Cookie: B1SESSION=" . $sessionId . "; ROUTEID=" . $routeId . ";"

                "NumAtCard" => (string) $ordrenummer,
                "DocDate" => substr($created, 0, 10),
                "DocDueDate" => date("Y-m-d"),
                "DocCurrency" => (string) $valuta,
                "DocumentLines" => $orderlinesArray,
                "Comments" => "Generert fra LOGONv3 (TransferID: {$sapTransferID})",
                "U_Lokasjon" => (string) $lokasjon ?? ''
            ];

            $postJson = json_encode($payload, JSON_UNESCAPED_UNICODE);

            //echo $postJson.'<br><br>';
            //Post order to SAP...

            $curl = curl_init();
            curl_setopt($curl, CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER, $headers);
            curl_setopt($curl, CURLOPT_URL, $host . ":" . $port . "/b1s/v1/Orders");
            curl_setopt($curl, CURLOPT_RETURNTRANSFER, true);
            curl_setopt($curl, CURLOPT_POST, true);
            curl_setopt($curl, CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS, $postJson);
            curl_setopt($curl, CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYHOST, FALSE);
            curl_setopt($curl, CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYPEER, false);

            $response = curl_exec($curl);
            curl_close($curl);
...

entry.title: Re: Intelligent Application - Why is Data stored twice in...
entry.content:
Hi,

That's a valid question, i did some research and came out with the following findings. I am sure this will help.

  1. Landing Zone (Object Store)
    • Data from the source system (e.g., S/4HANA Cloud or other systems) is extracted and first landed as files in the Object Store.
    • This is like a raw storage area where incoming data is staged.
  2. Ingestion Layer (Datasphere Space)
    • From the Object Store, the Replication Flow (or Pipeline) moves the data into SAP Datasphere Space.

Here, the data is structured, modeled, and made available as Data Products for consumption in SAC or other applications.

So yes – the data is physically stored twice in BDC:

  • Once as a file in Object Store (raw form).

  • Again in Datasphere Space (structured, query-ready form).

Why this design?

  • Separation of concerns: Object Store acts as the persistent raw data layer (immutable, cost-efficient). Datasphere is the semantic, analytics-ready layer.

  • Resilience & reprocessing: If ingestion or transformations fail, the raw file in Object Store can be reprocessed without going back to S/4.

  • Scalability: Object Store can handle huge data dumps cheaply, while Datasphere optimizes for analytics and semantic modeling.

Hope this helps.

regards

Giri

entry.title: Enhancements to SAP Community - September 2025
entry.content:
• New Standards for Tags and Labels
  • <code> tag
  • Table of Contents (TOC)
  • Dismissible global banner
  • Glow/Dark Mode Fixes
  • Creation Date Filter on Feeds

We have been busy lately, and didn't only launch new developer forums this week, but we also released a few other features. 

New Standards for Tags and Labels 

We are setting limitations for the number of SAP Managed Tags, user tags, and labels that members can add to blog posts, questions, discussions, and documents. With these new standards, members will only be able to add ten of each type – meaning a maximum of ten SAP Managed Tags, ten user tags, and ten labels per piece of content. 

By setting these limitations, we’ll make it easier for members to find relevant content that interests them – as excessive tagging and labeling causes confusion in feeds and may frustrate members who receive notifications for posts that don’t match their expectations. Too many tags can also make it difficult for members to identify what a question is actually about, or if a blog post contains information that appeals to them. That’s why fewer tags are better – and why these new limitations have become necessary. 

Adding the right mix of SAP Managed Tags, user tags, and labels helps members locate what they want, so it’s important to understand what these selections represent – and equally important to be disciplined when picking them. 

SAP Managed Tags come from the official list of SAP offerings, as shown here. Every blog post, question, discussion, and document require at least one SAP Managed Tag for publication. As a best practice, we recommend no more than three of these tags. It is possible to subscribe to an SAP Managed Tag so that you will receive notifications of new content about that product.

Complementing SAP Managed Tags are user tags. These tags are created by the users themselves. User tags aren’t tied to any official list, so members have flexibility when coming up with these additional tags. 

We’re setting a maximum of ten for labels as well.  
Members can subscribe to a label to get notifications of new content associated with that label.

While a minimum of one SAP Managed Tag is mandatory for most content types, user tags and labels are generally optional – although a single label may also be mandatory for certain groups/boards. If you attempt to add more than ten, you’ll receive an error message when attempting to publish, and you’ll need to reduce the number before you can post the content. 

Note that these changes won’t impact existing content, so if you’ve been in the habit of adding dozens of tags and labels to content you’ve published in the past, you won’t need to go back and trim anything. But if you do try to make changes to this content (such as to correct a typo that you notice in an old blog post), you will need to make sure the post doesn’t exceed the maximum number of tags and/or labels. The system won’t let you update old content unless it meets the new standards for tagging and labeling. 

By applying SAP Managed Tags, user tags, and labels effectively (and judiciously), you’ll ensure that your content finds the right audience. Limiting the choices, to keep content more focused, will help your posts perform better, draw proper attention, and create a better experience for all.  



<code> tag

We have added the ability to use the <code> tag for inline code elements. 
The <code> HTML element displays its contents styled in a colored monospaced font to indicate that the text is a short fragment of code in the body of a post. 
For longer pieces of code, please continue to use the "Insert/Edit code sample" functionality of the editor. 

To use the <code> tag, you need to open the HTML/Source code editor from the toolbar: 

Next, you add the <code> tag around the inline code fragment you would like to share, or highlight in your post: 

The published version of the post will look like this:


Table of Contents (TOC)

We have also added the ability to add a Table of Contents (TOC) to both blog posts and documents (Knowledge Base articles). 
To use the Table of Contents functionality, you start by writing/adding your text in the editor after which you click the new "Table of Contents" button in the toolbar: 



Clicking the button will open a "Manage Table of Contents" pop-up which will give you a preview of the TOCs, including an overview over the TOC options: 

After clicking "Save", you will see a new "Table of Contents" menu at the top of the editor. Clicking this will open the "Manage Table of Contents" pop-up any time you need to access it: 

The TOCs in the final published post will look like this: 

 

Dismissible global banner

You asked if we could make the global banners dismissible, which we did. 
Clicking the "x" in the banner will now remove the banner, until a new banner is added. 



There will still be some areas of the community where the banners cannot be removed, for instance in our "Archived Content" area, where we have permanent banners informing users that content there is set to read-only. 


Glow/Dark Mode Fixes

Various Glow (new design) and Dark mode fixes were released this month as well.

For instance:

  • the Label widget has been hidden in some boards
  • the word ‘Board’ has been removed from the top of feeds to allow for the content to be moved up
  • Spacing around headers in posts have been fixed

Creation Date Filter on Feeds

A ‘Creation Date’ sorting option has been added on the various feeds to allow for easier sorting of the various posts. This is the default sorting of all feeds:

entry.title: Time-series Forecasting with Generative AI: Integrating HANA AI Toolkit with Joule in SAP Build Code
entry.content:
Introduction

In the era of AI-first development, embedding intelligence into business applications is no longer optional—it's expected. As an application developer working on SAP BTP, I was recently tasked with enhancing our Sales Refunds Analysis application with a forecasting component. The challenge? I’m not a data scientist.

But thanks to the HANA AI Toolkit and Joule, SAP Build Code’s AI co-pilot, I was able to build a robust forecasting solution—without needing deep expertise in machine learning.

In this blog, I’ll walk you through how I used a simple slash command /hana-ai to interact with the HANA AI Toolkit via Joule, and how this integration empowered me to build, evaluate, and deploy a forecasting model in just a few conversational steps.

What is the HANA AI Toolkit?

The Generative AI Toolkit for SAP HANA Cloud is a powerful suite of tools designed to simplify the use of SAP HANA’s machine learning and vector capabilities. It includes:

  • Conversational agents for building forecasting models
  • Tools for selecting and applying ML algorithms
  • SmartDataFrame interface for natural language data exploration
  • Vector and embedding services
  • Code generation components for SAP HANA Cloud scenarios

Meet Joule: Your AI Co-Pilot in SAP Build Code

Joule is SAP Build Code’s generative AI assistant, designed to help developers write, generate, and integrate code faster. With the new /hana-ai slash command, Joule can now directly interact with the HANA AI Toolkit—bringing ML capabilities into the hands of every developer.

My Use Case: Forecasting Sales Refunds

Here’s how I used the integration to build a forecasting model for our Sales Refunds application:

1. Initiating the Forecasting Task

/hana-ai I am tasked to create a forecasting application, do you have any hana-ai tools which can help me with that?

Joule responded with a list of ready-to-use forecasting tools like:

  • additive_model_forecast_fit_and_save
  • automatic_timeseries_fit_and_save
  • intermittent_forecast

 

2. Exploring the Data

/hana-ai Show me the first 5 rows from SALES_REFUNDS table

Joule fetched the data, helping me understand the structure and values.

 

3. Generating a Dataset Report

A detailed HTML report was generated, giving me insights into data quality and structure.

 

4. Time Series Analysis

 
/hana-ai Please analyse and check the time series data in the table SALES_REFUNDS_TRAIN

Joule analyzed the dataset and provided:

  • Stationarity check (KPSS test)
  • Seasonality detection
  • Intermittency level
  • Suggested algorithms and many more details

 

5. Choosing the Right Algorithm

 
/hana-ai Which time series forecasting algorithm do you suggest?

Based on the data characteristics, Joule recommended the Additive Model Forecast.

 

6. Building the Forecast Model

 
/hana-ai Build a forecast model and save it as Refunds-ForecastModel

The model was trained and saved with versioning support.

 

 

7. Generating Predictions

 
/hana-ai Apply the latest forecast model to the SALES_REFUNDS_PREDICT table

Predictions were stored in a new table, ready for analysis.

8. Visualizing the Forecast

 
/hana-ai Generate a forecast line plot

A visual plot was generated to compare actual vs. predicted values.

 

 

9. Evaluating Accuracy

 
/hana-ai Evaluate the forecast accuracy

Joule returned key metrics:

  • MAPE: 8.41%
  • MSE: 16,807,501.57
  • RMSE: 4,099.70

 

10. Generating CAP Artifacts

 
/hana-ai Generate CAP artifacts for the forecast model

Joule generated and offered to integrate the artifacts directly into my CAP project.

Outcome

With just a few conversational commands, I was able to:

  • Analyze time series data
  • Select the right forecasting model
  • Train and evaluate the model
  • Visualize and integrate the results into my application

All without writing a single line of ML code.

Key Takeaways

  • AI democratization: Developers without ML expertise can now build intelligent features.
  • Conversational development: Joule + HANA AI Toolkit enables natural language-driven workflows.
  • Enterprise-ready: The integration supports versioning, evaluation, and CAP artifact generation.

What’s Next?

This is just the beginning. With the /hana-ai slash command, we’re opening the door to a wide range of AI-powered development scenarios—from classification to anomaly detection and beyond.

If you're building on SAP BTP and want to embed intelligence into your applications, give the HANA AI Toolkit and Joule a try. You might be surprised how far a conversation can take you.

entry.title: Re: RE-FX Contracts- Reversal
entry.content:
Hi RECEEPRV is the correct way to reverse. By default the "Reverse last run only" check box is ticket as that would avoid an accidental reversal of all the valuation postings. Most of the time only the last run would be needed to be reversed, but if there is a scenario to reverse all the valuation postings you can simply untick this box.

Just take extra care that you simulate first to avoid accidentally reversing too many contracts and use the correct parameters (e.g. cocd, contract number or process ID).

Regards, Andre

entry.title: Alternative Unit of Measures for different products
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community, 

We want to use the alternative unit of measures within our warehouse. We have following problem: 

Product A has BuoM Pieces, AuoM Meter and is usually handled in pieces.
Product B has BuoM Pieces, AuoM Meter and is usually handled in meter.

We maintained pieces as a Preferred Unit of Measure in Material Master for Product A, and meter for Product B.

To use meter as an alternative unit of measure during putaway within RFUI, we maintained meter as a stock specific of measure, but that leads Product A also processed in meters. If we do not maintain meter as a stock specific unit of measure, Product B would be handled also in Pieces, as this is the Base Unit of Measure for both Products.

How can we achieve our goal without deleting alternative unit of measures?

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: 5 pontos essenciais para o fechamento da fase REALIZE em projetos SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
entry.content:
A fase REALIZE, dentro da metodologia SAP Activate, é o momento em que tudo o que foi definido até aqui ganha vida: configurações são implementadas, extensões desenvolvidas, integrações validadas e testes executados.
O bom fechamento desta fase garante que o projeto chegue ao DEPLOY de forma estável, com riscos controlados e stakeholders confiantes.

O Roadmap da metodologia SAP Activate apresenta informações bem completas para apoio nesse momento. Mas caso precise de um guia para referência rápida, deixo abaixo os 5 pontos chave que devem ser considerados neste momento. Como mais referências, deixo ao final deste post o link para o Roadmap completo.

A seguir, compartilho os 5 pontos-chave que devem ser observados no encerramento do REALIZE:

1. Configurações e Extensões Concluídas

Todos os objetos de configuração e extensões (incluindo in-app e side-by-side) devem estar concluídos e documentados.

  • Escopo implementado de acordo com o backlog aprovado

  • Customizações testadas e validadas

  • Documentação funcional e técnica atualizada

Sem essa confirmação, o cutover e os testes finais ficam comprometidos.

2. Integrações Testadas e Estabilizadas

O REALIZE deve encerrar com as integrações já validadas.

  • Interfaces críticas funcionando de ponta a ponta

  • Conectividade e performance validadas

  • Monitoramento básico configurado

Isso reduz riscos de falhas sistêmicas no DEPLOY.

3. Testes de Negócio Concluídos (UAT)

Os User Acceptance Tests (UAT) são a validação final do negócio nesta fase.

  • Cenários críticos executados com aprovação formal dos Key Users

  • Defeitos críticos resolvidos ou com plano de correção definido

  • Evidências registradas para auditoria e governança

Avançar sem um UAT concluído gera insegurança na virada produtiva.

4. Estratégia e Execução de Migração de Dados

A fase REALIZE deve encerrar com a estratégia de dados já validada e ciclos de migração testados.

  • Mock loads realizados com taxas de sucesso aceitáveis

  • Regras de qualidade confirmadas

  • Responsáveis e janelas de execução do cutover definidos

Esse ponto é crítico: falhas de dados são um dos maiores riscos de um Go-Live.

5. Riscos, Governança e Plano de Cutover Formalizados

Por fim, deve-se garantir que a transição ao DEPLOY esteja estruturada.

  • Riscos atualizados no risk register

  • Plano de cutover documentado e aprovado

  • Governança pronta para tomada de decisão rápida na virada

Isso dá segurança para todos os stakeholders de que o projeto está pronto para a última etapa.

Conclusão

Encerrar bem o REALIZE significa ter: configurações concluídas, integrações testadas, UAT aprovado, dados validados e cutover planejado.
Com isso, o projeto segue para o DEPLOY com estabilidade, reduzindo riscos e garantindo confiança da liderança.

O resultado? Um Go-Live muito mais seguro e previsível, com o valor de negócio do SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition pronto para ser entregue.

Link para o Roadmap SAP Activate relacionado a esta etapa:

https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer/group/658F507A-D6F5-4B78-9EE1-0300C5F1E40F/roadmapcontentpage/a11ec6d657054bf9:FA163EAF25B21EEB8FC47DE9E728C8DB

entry.title: Re: MD01N Behavior: Provision Stock at Subcontractor Loca...
entry.content:
Good day @Manohar_Rm 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at MRP Area Subcontractor , Subcontracting Without Source Location & ME2ON – Subcontracting for more details.

To summarise, in MD01N, subcontracting stock at vendor is not treated as unrestricted-use stock at plant level. Therefore, when you do not define subcontractor MRP areas, the MRP ignores this stock and generates additional purchase requisitions. This is a common behaviour.

However, there are ways to resolve that situation:

  • First is for you to set up subcontractor MRP areas. Only after that does MRP consider vendor stock as available for covering subcontracting requirements.
  • If you do not consider MRP areas as an option, there is no standard way to force MD01N to treat subcontractor stock as unrestricted. In that case, you would need to either:
    • Need to manually monitor subcontractor stock,
    • a process redesign, or
    • a build a custom enhancement which is only possible in on-prem/private cloud.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: 5 Essential Points for Successfully Closing REALIZE in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects
entry.content:
The REALIZE phase in the SAP Activate methodology is where everything defined so far comes to life: system configuration, extensions, integrations, data migration cycles, and business testing.

Closing this phase properly ensures the project enters DEPLOY in a stable, controlled way, with stakeholders confident in the Go-Live readiness.

The SAP Activate Methodology Roadmap provides comprehensive information to support this stage. However, if you need a quick reference guide, below are the 5 key points that should be considered at this moment. For additional references, I’ve included at the end of this post the link to the full Roadmap.

1. Completed Configurations and Extensions

All system configurations and required extensions (in-app and side-by-side) must be finalized and documented.

  • Scope implemented according to the approved backlog

  • Custom developments tested and validated

  • Updated functional and technical documentation

Without this confirmation, the cutover and final tests become highly risky.

2. Stabilized and Tested Integrations

REALIZE should close with end-to-end integrations validated and running.

  • Critical interfaces tested with positive results

  • Connectivity and performance verified

  • Monitoring in place for key scenarios

This reduces the risk of systemic failures during DEPLOY.

3. Business Testing (UAT) Completed

The User Acceptance Tests (UAT) are the ultimate business validation in REALIZE.

  • Critical business scenarios executed with formal sign-off by Key Users

  • Critical defects resolved or mitigation plan in place

  • Test evidence documented for audit and governance purposes

Proceeding without UAT completion compromises confidence in the Go-Live.

4. Data Migration Strategy Executed and Validated

The REALIZE phase must close with a validated data migration strategy and tested mock loads.

  • Trial migration cycles executed with acceptable success rates

  • Data quality rules confirmed

  • Ownership and cutover windows defined

Data issues are among the highest risks during Go-Live; preparation here is critical.

5. Risk Register, Governance, and Cutover Plan Formalized

Finally, the project must ensure a structured transition into DEPLOY.

  • Risk register updated with mitigation strategies

  • Cutover plan documented and approved

  • Governance ready to support fast decision-making during cutover

Conclusion

Closing the REALIZE phase means having: completed configurations, stabilized integrations, approved UAT, validated data migration, and a formalized cutover plan.
With these elements in place, the project can confidently move into DEPLOY with reduced risks and increased trust from leadership.

The outcome? A Go-Live that is more predictable, stable, and aligned to business value with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Link to the SAP Activate Roadmap related to this phase:

https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer/group/658F507A-D6F5-4B78-9EE1-0300C5F1E40F/roadmapcontentpage/a11ec6d657054bf9:FA163EAF25B21EEB8FC47DE9E728C8DB

entry.title: Everyday issues: SAP HANA database parameters (recommended by SAP) not configured properly.
entry.content:
• Why was this blog post created?
  • How to check/detect if SAP HANA parameters are set incorrectly?
  • What is the conclusion?
  • Everyday issues
  • Other article
  • Useful bookmark
  • Do you have further questions?
  • Contribution

last updated: 2025-10-01

Why was this blog post created?

Many times, deeper investigations are performed, for example, regarding general performance errors, without the basic SAP HANA parameters being set correctly. Inadequate parameter settings can be responsible for various severe issues. First of all, it is necessary to set the parameters correctly. Without these, the system will most likely not function optimally. 

Do not perform deep analysis until the SAP HANA recommended parameters are properly configured. Many times, setting these parameters correctly will solve some (or even all) problems on its own.

How to check/detect if SAP HANA parameters are set incorrectly?

1. 2903141 - Best practice configuration checks for SAP HANA

With the help of the HANA_Configuration_Parameters report these parameters can be checked easily.

2. 3409480 - The importance of proper tracking and maintenance of parameters in SAP HANA environments

The SAP Knowledge Base Articles contains all relevant information to properly maintain these parameters.

What is the conclusion?

In the absence of parameters belonging to the SAP HANA database, which is highly recommended by SAP, it is not worth performing any further investigation (belongs to performance, memory, etc.). This is a basic and primary step, and this parameter check must be performed not only after installation but also after a version update.

Everyday issues

✍️ Everyday issues: Unmanaged SAP HANA database backup.
✍️ Everyday issues: There is no miracle or magic. SAP HANA database needs memory.

Other article

✍️ Where can I find knowledge and information belongs to SAP HANA?
✍️ Where can I find information about the available tools for SAP HANA (all types of use)?

Useful bookmark

🔖 2872774 – Bookmark of Frequently Asked Questions for SAP HANA
🔖 3311408 – Bookmark of SQL Statement Collection reports for SAP HANA
🔖 2658020 – List of SAP HANA SQL Error Codes

Do you have further questions?

Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have question or observation regarding the article.
Q&A link for SAP HANA: https://answers.sap.com/tags/73554900100700000996 

Contribution

If you find any missing information belongs to the topic, please let me know. I am happy to add the new content. My intention is to maintain the content continuously to keep the info up-to-date.

Release Information

Release DateDescription
2025.10.01First/initial Release of the SAP Blog Post documentation (Technical Article).

entry.title: SAP’s Commitment to Business Continuity that Protects what Matters
entry.content:
When people want to guard valuable items from their personal collections, they turn to protected places, such as banks, where they can rest safely, shielded from any unanticipated events. For centuries, individuals have entrusted institutions to safeguard what is most treasured by them, whether personal belongings or other assets. In the same fashion, SAP is dedicated to assisting customers protect their business value.

Disruptions can happen at any time. The difference stands in how well-prepared customers can be for these challenging periods. For example, Black Friday and Cyber Monday are the busiest shopping periods of the year for retailers. During these events, downtime or poor performance can cost millions in lost sales and customer trust, which could hamper core business operations.

Holiday Season Readiness Program

To support industries processes during these times, SAP enhanced the Holiday Season Readiness Program for Commerce Cloud customers. This joint initiative between Support, Engineering, and Cloud Operations ensured retailers were fully equipped with:

  • Introduction of a Preventative Care Model powered by AI and automation, using the Agentic AI framework to proactively detect and even resolve issues before they impacted customers.
  • Weekly health checks, 360° action plans, proactive cases, and a 24x7 global control room with real-time monitoring and on-site staffing.

SAP for Me

Aligned with our commitment to being a reliable partner, SAP for Me is evolving into a customer’s digital companion, in one of the most exciting innovations within SAP. It’s no longer just a portal; it’s becoming a central hub for transparency, guidance, and predictive insights. It holds:

  • AI-driven transparency - SAP for Me aggregates critical alerts, metrics, and insights across a customer’s entire SAP product portfolio. With the integration of Business AI, it now gives visibility into AI unit availability, consumption, and expirations, helping customers avoid surprises and plan proactively.
  • Proactive business assurance - Instead of waiting for a billing or system issue, SAP for Me provides real-time and predictive views into usage, health, and risks. For instance, customers can track consumption trends by product and feature, updated hourly, and receive early warnings when capacity is at risk.
  • Simplified control - All AI usage is linked to finance and legal statements, so customers get a single source of truth that connects technical consumption with business accountability. This prevents overspend, protects return on investment (ROI), and ensures contractual clarity.
  • Continuous innovation - SAP is expanding SAP for Me with embedded AI copilots and guided recommendations, so in the future, customers won’t just see metrics — they’ll get actionable guidance on how to optimize systems and safeguard value.

Ongoing support and maintenance are critical to sustaining business value with SAP systems. A successful go-live is just the starting point; systems need to remain secure, compliant, and optimized as business needs to evolve. With proactive monitoring, automation, and AI-driven insights, customers can prevent disruptions, reduce risk, and maintain high availability. In practice, this means lower operational costs, higher uptime, and continuous ROI over the entire lifecycle of their SAP investment.

Just as we expect care when trusting our valuables to others, SAP is committed to safeguarding business value, providing seamless experiences that protect decisive revenue and build sustained trust.

A special thanks to Keith Ho, Customer Engagement Lead, and Manoj Gupta, SAP experts who have contributed to this article.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q3-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation
  • Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items
  • GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation
  • Onboarding Booster
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Customer Success Stories: KNAPP & Tyrolit
  • Upcoming Partner Webinars
  • Additional Information

 

ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation

Transportation can be a major contributor to Scope 3 emissions, yet calculating its impact has mostly been complex and manual. With the new ERP‑centric transport footprint calculation, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a capability that leverages your existing ERP master and transactional data to automate and scale transport emission calculations. This means you can move from spreadsheets and estimates to actual, auditable results that integrate seamlessly into both corporate and product carbon footprints.

Instead of building transport models from scratch, the solution now derives upstream and internal transport activities from Goods Receipt from Supplier, Goods Return to Supplier, and Goods Transfer data, and then calculates the footprint per activity, route, and leg. In practical terms, a transport activity is determined as the movement of specific products in given quantities between two locations under defined conditions. The system brings together master data, transaction details, and transport settings to identify source and target locations, the mode of transport, and whether goods move under ambient or temperature-controlled conditions. It then builds optimal transport routes via connection points such as airports, seaports, inland ports, and railway stations, before applying the relevant emission factors to calculate the footprint.

 

In the following, I’ll briefly summarize the required process steps and introduce the new apps. For detailed information, see Calculating Transport Footprints Using Business Transactions.

To use the new approach, start with importing transport-relevant master data, so routing and distances work out-of-the-box. Products now carry a Custom Temperature Condition, and SAP provides a default mapping to Ambient. If you need temperature-controlled transport, create your own custom conditions and map them to the standard values (Ambient or Temperature-Controlled). Locations and Plants now support addresses and geo-coordinates, and Business Partners can be imported with Supplier and Carrier roles, including address data tied to supplier IDs.

Then you can configure your inventory scope and in Transport Details set the Data Source to Standard (Business Transactions). Newly created scopes default to Standard, while existing scopes remain on Classic until you switch them.

For maintaining transport connection points – like seaports, inland ports, airports, railway stations – go to the Manage Locations app, where you already find SAP-delivered content for seaports and airports to help kick-start sea and air routes.

Next, configure how goods typically move in your network with the new Manage Transport Settings app. Define haul types and distances – short haul defaults to 1500 km and can be adapted – and specify the primary mode of transport from supplier locations to one or all plants, optionally by product group. The same supplier-to-plant mode applies to returns back to the supplier. For internal logistics, create directional settings for movements between plants.

With settings in place, use the new Manage Transport Activities app to generate transport activities for your chosen scope and period from the ERP transactions. Once activities are clean, generate the corresponding routes and legs. In case of inconsistencies, the app guides you with messages helping you to resolve before calculation.

Emission factors for the different modes of transport are managed in the new Manage Transport Operation Footprints app, and you can maintain them in the UI directly or import via file.

Finally, run the transport calculation in the new Calculate Transport Footprints app and review results per activity, route, and leg.

In the Calculate Footprints app, the Data Readiness tab lists transport data as one of the data types. Transport is now a first-class citizen across the analytics experience. In organizational footprint inventories, transport data becomes mandatory whenever your scope uses Standard and transport-relevant value chain steps are enabled. Transport footprints are created as input items to products, if a carrier is specified, the corresponding business partner footprint is used as the utilized item, otherwise the input is shown as Unknown Carrier. You can see transport-related product and business partner items in the Manage Footprint Results app, and analyze Scope 3.4 emissions in depth in the Footprint Overview app.

A quick note on provisioning: The new apps require explicit role assignment, role names are case-sensitive, and write access requires both read and write roles. If you’re moving from the classic transport approach, reimport your enhanced master data for Plants, Business Partners, Products, and relevant Locations via file or API, then switch your inventory scopes to Standard (Business Transactions). Keep scopes on Classic if you plan to recalculate them using the classic transport apps. With these pieces in place, the new transport calculation streamlines data preparation, strengthens routing fidelity, and brings transport emissions seamlessly into your product and corporate footprint story.

 

Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items

For decarbonizing your company and products, it’s crucial to have full transparency into what’s actually driving emissions across the value chain. While total product footprints are useful, they often leave a critical question unanswered: Where exactly do these emissions come from? Without that level of granularity, it’s difficult to identify hotspots, prioritize reduction efforts, or make informed decisions that lead to real impact. To address this, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management now includes a new feature in the Manage Footprint Results app: Source Input Items. This enhancement gives you a detailed view into the specific inputs that contribute to a product’s environmental footprint – enabling smarter, data-driven strategies for decarbonization.

 

Source input items represent the materials, energy, transport, and other resources used at the start of a process that result in emissions. With just a click on Generate, you can now explore these contributors for each footprint item (excluding items of type business partner, work in progress, production documents, and supplier). Note that source input items currently cannot yet be generated for calculation results involving cycles, this will be added in a future release.

The app provides you with various charts that instantly visualize emissions across lifecycle stages such as material acquisition, production, transport, and end-of-life treatment. These charts help you pinpoint the most emission-intensive stages and align your analysis with the GHG Protocol. You can also customize the view to match your specific reporting or decision-making needs. Below the chart, a consolidated table provides full transparency into each source input item.

With this enhancement, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management strengthens its role as an intuitive product fact sheet, empowering you to go beyond high-level metrics. You can now trace emissions to their source, understand their context, and take targeted action – whether that means switching suppliers, optimizing logistics, or redesigning products. For all information, see Viewing the Footprint Results on SAP Help.

 

GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation

One of the recurring challenges in tracking greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is the complexity and scale of data collection. Sustainability teams often need to gather activity and spend data from various business units, geographies, or partner organizations. To address these hurdles, we now released the GHG Data Forms API. This new public API empowers you to extend and tailor the GHG data collection process far beyond the core application: External workflows, survey applications, or even mobile apps can now retrieve, maintain, and push data directly into the GHG Data Forms in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. By decentralizing and parallelizing how and where environmental data is gathered, you can drive faster, more automated, and more consistent emission data capture across your full operational or organizational boundary. For technical details and integration guidelines, refer to the official API documentation on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

One powerful example of leveraging this API is through SAP Build Process Automation. With SAP Build workflows, you can automate and streamline sustainability data collection across multiple locations. The process begins by triggering a workflow, either manually or on a scheduled basis, then retrieving all relevant business activities and locations from SAP Sustainability Footprint Management using the API. Through parallel subprocesses for each location, you can enable simultaneous data collection and significantly reduce cycle time. Business users receive customizable forms – survey-style via SAP Build or ticket-style via SAP Task Center – delivered directly to the right people based on responsibility rules, with built-in notifications and reminders to keep the process moving. Once data is submitted, it’s routed for approval, and after validation, posted back to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and included into the overall footprint calculation. This approach provides flexibility, scalability, and compliance, helping sustainability teams focus on insights rather than manual tasks.

 

 

Onboarding Booster

With the introduction of the Onboarding Booster, we’re speeding up the time required for setting up am SAP Sustainability Footprint Management tenant on SAP BTP. The entire onboarding can now be completed in about 10 to 15 minutes through a guided, automated process. The booster is integrated into the SAP BTP cockpit and walks you through the essential steps: checking prerequisites, selecting the identity service, and either creating or choosing a subaccount. Once these steps are confirmed, the system takes over and performs the necessary configurations in the background. The result is a fully prepared environment that is ready for role assignment and productive use. This is more than just a time saver, it reduces complexity and lowers the barrier for customers to get started quickly and confidently. For detailed guidance, the full procedure is documented in our Help Portal: Setting Up Using Booster.

 

Other Release Highlights

We’ve redesigned the SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure for a more intuitive experience. New app groups offer logical organization, simplifying navigation and helping you to quickly find what you need. For more information, see Enhanced SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure.

You can now assign different location types (not just plants) to a single business activity, expanding flexibility, supporting more accurate form generation, and ensuring that business activities can be valid across multiple locations. See Creating Business Activities for more information.

Additionally, when setting your footprint inventory scope, plant assignments now ensure that only relevant forms are generated for your selected companies and locations. This prevents the creation of irrelevant forms, enhancing efficiency and streamlining the data collection process. Learn more here: Creating Business Activities.

 

Customer Success Stories

KNAPP AG, a global leader in intralogistics and warehouse automation, faced new challenges with the EU’s Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD), which raised the bar for ESG transparency. Instead of waiting for deadlines, KNAPP acted early, building a strong sustainability data foundation with SAP Sustainability solutions. Partnering with KPMG Austria, KNAPP implemented SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower to replace manual reporting with automated, integrated processes. These solutions consolidated over 200 sustainability metrics from across the business, delivering advanced carbon footprint calculations at both product and corporate levels. This gave KNAPP unprecedented visibility into emissions, resource use, and overall ESG impact. With audit-ready reporting in place, KNAPP achieved CSRD compliance well ahead of schedule and embedded sustainability insights into daily operations and strategic planning. This proactive approach turned compliance into a catalyst for transformation, accelerating their “now4tomorrow” program and ensuring their first sustainability report complements financial disclosures. Read the full story: Getting ahead of regulatory reporting to steer business process transformation.

Tyrolit is a global leader in abrasive tools and construction systems that operates across 48 companies and exports to 140+ countries. Also facing growing demands for transparent ESG reporting under CSRD, Tyrolit needed to move beyond fragmented systems and spreadsheets that made standardization and auditability difficult. To address this, Tyrolit deployed SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower, integrated via SAP Business Technology Platform. This centralized ESG data collection from SAP and third-party systems, aligned sustainability reporting with financial standards, and enabled advanced analytics for benchmarking and target setting. AI-powered automation reduced manual work, improved accuracy, and provided dashboards for 60+ managers to monitor 80+ ESG metrics. This resulted in measurable carbon reductions, less plastic packaging, and higher recycling rates. Tyrolit now uses data-driven insights to identify emission-saving opportunities and embed sustainability across the organization. Check the full story: Tooling up to unlock the sustainable value chain with a robust ESG data foundation.

 

Upcoming Partner Webinars

Staying ahead means staying informed, and this quarter again brings two opportunities exclusively for our partners to connect and learn more about SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Both webinars are free for partners with a valid SAP Learning Hub license.

The SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training is a biannual event designed to empower partners with in-depth product know-how, practical guidance, and the latest innovations across SAP Cloud ERP, the SAP Business Suite, AI-powered features, and more. On October 10, you can learn more about the latest updates in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange. Register for the session here: Sustainability Management and Carbon Accounting. For an overview of all sessions and their respective registration links check out: SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training 2025.

On November 5, the Meet the Expert Session returns. This highly interactive webinar is your chance to bring questions directly to the SAP experts from the Product Management and Customer Adoption teams. Gain practical insights, obtain answers to your questions, and deepen your expertise in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Register here: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management - Meet the Expert Q4 2025.

 

Additional Information

To learn more on how you can enhance the accuracy of your Scope 3.1 emissions reporting by transitioning from broad average data to precise, supplier-specific actuals, you should check out the blog post Implementing an Average to Actuals Strategy for Scope 3.1 by @CButzlaff. This article outlines a practical, phased approach for implementing this strategy using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange.

For a comprehensive guide on how to embed carbon accounting into your ERP and finance processes, have a look into the new SAP PRESS book Carbon Accounting for Sustainability with SAP. It explains how to capture sustainability data across your ERP landscape, calculate product- and company-level carbon footprints, and integrate results into finance through SAP Green Ledger. You’ll also learn how SAP Sustainability Data Exchange and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management enable accurate, auditable carbon data for decision-making and reporting.

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You’ll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: Agentic AI Testing for Greenfield S/4HANA Outbound Interfaces - Part 1
entry.content:
Intro

Outbound interfaces are the lifeline between your new S/4HANA Greenfield or Selective Data Transition system and the outside world. Customers, vendors, 3PL partners, they still expect the same EDI (or non-EDI) output messages, even if you’ve reshaped half your internal processes in the course of the SAP S/4HANA transformation.  

The real challenge? Functional consultants need to validate those outbound messages themselves, without waiting on an EDI provider, an integration colleague, or an EDI partner. That’s where Agentic AI validation with Int4 Suite comes in.

This playbook shows how functional consultants can independently test and validate outbound interfaces, step by step, without leaving the SAP S/4HANA + Int4 Suite environment.

Why functional consultants, not integration teams?

Most SAP projects (Greenfield, Selective Data Transition, or any other complex SAP S/4HANA upgrades) involve huge shifts inside SAP, but the outside world doesn’t care. Partner EDI flows must remain identical.

Traditionally, testing those flows meant:

  • Asking the EDI partner/provider for some sample messages
  • Trying to run the transaction in SAP S/4HANA
  • Asking the EDI provider to re-check/confirm outbound messages.
  • Pulling in a specialist from the integration team if something takes too long.
  • Repeating the same process multiple times with very little time to do it

Our approach flips this. It empowers the SAP functional consultant to:

  • Insert thousand of historical EDI messages from any productive system
  • Ask Int4 Suite to find the test data within those messages
  • Reproduce SAP transactions from historical payloads, like Sales Order Confirmation, Delivery (ASN) notification, Invoice Notification
  • Validate the EDI outbound messages directly in Int4 Suite by the functional consultant
  • The whole process takes minutes not hours and can be done hundreds of times per hour with no external dependencies (other partners)

No waiting on specialists, no bottlenecks, and much faster iterations.

Step 1: Reality-first message mining with Robotic Crawler

Use the Int4 Robotic Crawler to load hundreds or thousands of real historical messages (EDI or otherwise) into Int4 Suite. These are not toy examples — they’re your actual outbound payloads as they once moved through production.

Figure - Int4 Suite Robotic Crawler can fetch EDI messages from any supported archive or integration platform on mass scale 

Why it matters: Consultants can work with authentic data, not spec sheets or made-up test cases.

Step 2: Conversational selection of test cases

Functional consultants don’t need to master payload filtering. Instead, they can simply chat with the agent to select which messages they want to test.

Want to see all outbound orders from a specific customer? Or deliveries with a particular Incoterm? Just ask the agent.

Figure - select a historical EDI messages using different criteria (business document, partner, material, etc.) and use this data for testing 

Why it matters: Test-case discovery becomes intuitive, not a technical exercise.

Step 3: Reconstruct SAP business objects from payloads

Once a message is selected, the consultant can instantly recreate a business document (e.g., a Sales Order) inside S/4HANA using the data from that outbound message.

Figure - creating a sales order using the data from the historical EDI message as input 

Now you have a living document in S/4HANA, built directly from the same payload your partners receive.

Why it matters: Consultants can validate the end-to-end logic of their own functional processes, with no dependency on integration experts.

Step 4: Agentic comparison of original vs. new outbound message

After posting the new Sales Order (or Delivery, or Invoice), the consultant sends the newly generated outbound reference back to the AI agent. The agent compares this outbound message to the original one from Step 1.

Figure - use the historical EDI message to compare with the new one and fetch is by just supplying the new order reference number 

Are they still identical? Has anything in S/4HANA configuration changed the outbound structure? Did the partner-facing fields remain untouched?

Figure - display the comparison of the two EDI messages (original and the new one) to fix any SAP S/4HANA configuration issues (like line item category determination, substitutions, calculations, etc.) 

Why it matters: Consultants get a precise answer immediately, without needing to export messages into external systems or call for backup.

Who benefits from this approach?

  • Functional consultants in SAP S/4HANA Greenfield or Selective Data Transition projects who must ensure message stability despite deep process changes.
  • Project teams that want faster, independent validation without pulling scarce EDI resources.
  • Business stakeholders who need assurance that partners will keep receiving the same documents as before, no surprises.

Who is this not for?

  • Integration consultants looking to stress-test iFlows or middleware mappings — this isn’t their playground. Int4 Suite has other features to facilite those requirements.
  • EDI providers who validate full partner connectivity, that’s still their domain.
  • Pure developers focused on code-level regression, this approach is tailored for business-facing validation.

Why it matters for S/4HANA programs where EDI messages remain the same but SAP S/4HANA can change? 

Outbound interfaces are always the fragile bridge in any migration. By equipping functional consultants with agentic AI validation, you:

  • Shorten test cycles.
  • Reduce reliance on external partners.
  • Increase confidence in project quality.

Outbound messages stay consistent, partners stay happy, and your SAP S/4HANA Greenfield program keeps its velocity.

This approach isn’t about replacing integration experts — it’s about freeing functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves the system is still what the outside world expects. It’s the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction interface validation in SAP transformations.
